title: INTERSPEECH_2013_21_abs

sentences.text: This work proposes a new research direction to address the lack of structures in traditional n-gram models .
It is based on a weakly supervised dependency parser that can model speech syntax without relying on any annotated training corpus .
Labeled data is replaced by a few hand-crafted rules that encode basic syntactic knowledge .
Bayesian inference then samples the rules , disambiguating and combining them to create complex tree structures that maximize a discriminative model 's posterior on a target unlabeled corpus .
This posterior encodes sparse se-lectional preferences between a head word and its dependents .
The model is evaluated on English and Czech newspaper texts , and is then validated on French broadcast news transcriptions .

Entity-this_work.label: This work
Entity-this_work.description: A novel approach to dependency parsing for modeling speech syntax without relying on annotated training corpora, proposing a new research direction to address the lack of structures in traditional n-gram models.

Entity-a_new_research_direction.label: a new research direction
Entity-a_new_research_direction.description: A novel approach to addressing the limitations of traditional n-gram models by proposing a weakly supervised dependency parser for modeling speech syntax without relying on annotated training corpora.

Entity-it.label: It
Entity-it.description: A new research direction proposed to address the lack of structures in traditional n-gram models, based on a weakly supervised dependency parser.

Entity-that_can_model_speech_syntax_with.label: that can model speech syntax without relying on any annotated training corpus
aliases: that can model speech syntax without relying on any annotated training corpus
Entity-that_can_model_speech_syntax_with.description: A type of weakly supervised dependency parser that models speech syntax without requiring an annotated training corpus.

mentions.local_name: that can model speech syntax without relying on any annotated training corpus

Entity-a_weakly_supervised_dependency_pa.label: a weakly supervised dependency parser
Entity-a_weakly_supervised_dependency_pa.description: A machine learning algorithm that analyzes sentence structure and relationships between words, trained using a limited amount of labeled data and hand-crafted rules, rather than relying on extensive annotated training corpora.

Entity-traditional_n-gram_model.label: traditional n-gram models
Entity-traditional_n-gram_model.description: A type of statistical language processing model that analyzes sequences of n items (e.g., characters, words) and uses this information to make predictions or classify text.

Entity-a_discriminative_model_s_posterio.label: a discriminative model's posterior on a target unlabeled corpus
aliases: a discriminative model's posterior on a target unlabeled corpus
Entity-a_discriminative_model_s_posterio.description: The probability distribution of a dependency parser that maximizes its likelihood given an input text, based on learned rules and syntactic knowledge.

mentions.local_name: a discriminative model's posterior on a target unlabeled corpus

Entity-the_rule.label: the rules
Entity-the_rule.description: Hand-crafted syntactic rules used in a weakly supervised dependency parser to encode basic syntactic knowledge and create complex tree structures.

Entity-the_lack_of_structure_in_traditio.label: the lack of structures in traditional n-gram models
aliases: the lack of structures in traditional n-gram models
Entity-the_lack_of_structure_in_traditio.description: A limitation inherent in conventional n-gram modeling approaches, characterized by the absence of structural representations.

Entity-this_posterior.label: This posterior
Entity-this_posterior.description: A measure of probability that represents the likelihood of selecting specific dependencies (head words and their dependents) given a discriminative model.

Entity-weakly_supervised_dependency_pars.label: weakly supervised dependency parser
Entity-weakly_supervised_dependency_pars.description: A type of algorithm or software that uses weak supervision to parse dependencies, rather than relying on fully labeled training data.

aliases: sparse se-lectional preferences between a head word and its dependents
Entity-sparse_se-lectional_preference_be.description: The concept of sparse selectional preferences refers to the tendency for certain words (head words) to have limited or specific relationships with their dependent words, such as grammatical dependencies.

Entity-discriminative_model.description: A statistical machine learning algorithm designed to predict class labels based on input features, often used for classification tasks.

Entity-head_word.description: A fundamental unit of language that conveys meaning through its form, often used as the core or central element of a phrase or sentence.

summary: This work proposes a new research direction to address the lack of structures in traditional n-gram models . It is based on a weakly supervised dependency parser that can model speech syntax without relying on any annotated training corpus . Labeled data is replaced by a few hand-crafted rules that encode basic syntactic knowledge . Bayesian inference then samples the rules , disambiguating and combining them to create complex tree structures that maximize a discriminative model 's posterior on a target unlabeled corpus . This posterior encodes sparse se-lectional preferences between a head word and its dependents . The model is evaluated on English and Czech newspaper texts , and is then validated on French broadcast news transcriptions .

Predicate-proposes.label: proposes
Predicate-proposes.description: To propose something means to suggest or recommend it as an idea or plan for consideration and potential implementation. The predicate 'proposes' indicates that the subject (in this case, a work) presents or advocates for the object (a new research direction), implying endorsement, support, or initiation of the proposed concept.

Predicate-lack_of_structures_in.label: lack of structures in
Predicate-lack_of_structures_in.description: The predicate 'lack of structures in' indicates a relationship between the subject and object where the subject lacks internal organization or coherence within itself, which is reflected by the presence of the lack of such structure within the object. This predicate highlights the absence of structural elements that would typically provide meaning, order, or clarity to the subject.

Predicate-is_based_on.label: is based on
Predicate-is_based_on.description: Indicates that the subject relies on or has its foundation in the object. The predicate 'is based on' suggests a relationship of dependence, where the subject's existence, validity, or functionality is grounded in the characteristics, principles, or methods described by the object.

Predicate-can_model.label: can model
Predicate-can_model.description: The predicate 'can model' indicates that a subject has the capability or ability to represent or describe an object using some kind of abstract representation. This can involve creating a mental or computational framework for understanding, analyzing, or generating the object's structure, patterns, or relationships.

Predicate-model.label: model
Predicate-model.description: To represent or simulate something (e.g. a system, process, or phenomenon) using abstract concepts, rules, or patterns, often to facilitate understanding, analysis, prediction, or generation.

Predicate-replaced_by.label: replaced by
Predicate-replaced_by.description: The predicate 'replaced by' indicates a substitution or alternative relationship between two entities. It suggests that one entity (the subject) has been substituted, superseded, or taken the place of another entity (the object), often implying a change or improvement.

Predicate-samples.label: samples
Predicate-samples.description: To sample means to select or extract a subset of instances from a larger population or dataset, often for purposes such as testing hypotheses, validating models, or evaluating performance. The predicate 'samples' connects the subject (a process or method) with the object (the rules or underlying principles being applied), indicating that the subject is using the object to generate this sample.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject is a specific instance or example of a more general concept or category represented by the object. The relationship between the subject and object is one of classification, where the subject is a narrower or more specialized version of the object.
